admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory
            with sustainability considered highly likely. Overall, the
            World Bank's performance is assessed as satisfactory,
            despite the lack of attention to the implementation of some
            of the policy components in the "middle years" of
            the project. Overall, Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            However, there were some significant procurement delays and
            perhaps of even greater concern, the lack of recognition of
            the importance of safeguard issues during the early years of
            project implementation. There are four important lessons
            cited in this report. First, if the Bank expects to
            influence reform and change, it must make a long-term
            commitment, and build a long-term relationship with its
            client agencies. Genuine railway reform takes time in most
            countries. Second, the Bank should never lose sight of the
            fact that economic or political factors well beyond the
            scope of this project can be major determinants of project
            success or failure. Third, a very large project with many
            investments and institutional development components will be
            expensive for both the Bank and our clients to manage and
            supervise. Finally, the client must fully appreciate the
            importance and value of the Bank's safeguard policies
            at the project. The Bank aggravated the problem by
            continually "raising the bar."
